title: Can Audacity be used to make a voice recording sound better? - Quora

response.answer_text: Having used Audacity extensively, I can certainly vouch for it's ability to make a voice sound its best. When I turn in an audition, or use the program for narration, I almost always employ some of the many available plugins to make what I've recorded sound more pleasing to the ear. I may use a compressor to make it sound fuller and more even throughout, a high pass filter to subtly remove minor pops, etc. I typically don't want to alter my natural voice too much, to avoid angering the client when I show up and sound nothing like the audition I submitted. If I did want to change my voice, however, there are plugins that would let me do that, as well. I can change the pitch, tempo, and almost any other aspect of the performance. As Patrick has already pointed out, however, this is no substitute for having a talented, capable narrator, with a pleasant voice, to begin with. I can tell you from experience that trying to fix poor-quality narration in post-production can be excruciating, and should be avoided, if at all possible.

Audacity has more effects than anyone could use I think. My favorite for increasing the presence of a voice is to add a touch of pseudo stereo.Nyquist Effect Plug-ins Also adding around 6db at 315hz and around 2000hz and 4000hz with graphic equalizer and rolling off the top frequencies. Here are some resources if you have time to read them and try them out. No affiliate links contained. How To Fix Weak Voice or Cheap Microphone With Audacity

If your talking editing yes, you can use Audacity to do editing. If your recording is low boost the volume with a compressor or a limiter, use the Eq to tweak the tone of your voice to get it to sound clearer and more crisp. But you'll need a good voice talent to ensure your piece is sounds consistent and even, as well as to get a good conversational sound overall.

If you are talking about making it sound like a professional announcer, there is NO software for that. You'd have to rely on boring old talent, training and experience for that.  It is possible that using Audacity could help you get a CLEARER recording of your actual voice, and that might make it easier for your listener to understand  you.

Your best bet is to start out with a good voice talent so you have strong material to begin with. You can do things like modify pitch/add effects to the voice so you can change how it sounds, but if the initial person doing the voiceover work doesn't have a good cadence and natural ability to speak on mic, it's not going to improve regardless of how much post-editing you do.
